pr_title: [QS-1] Add hard limits to gossip queues

timeline.message: Ignore future items from the far future
Keep ordering information on pending items
Use non-concurrent collections and synchronize access
Set hard limit on number of items in PendingPool

timeline.bodyText: if the while clause is true and the to remove item is null, doesn't that mean the max items is less than 1? It seems a bit redundant, or we might want to just throw an error in this scenario to show that max items shouldn't have been set to 1. Or am I missing something?
timeline.author: cemozerr

replies.bodyText: It is redundant - only added it because IntelliJ was complaining about a possible NullPointerException.  I don't think it hurts anything to be extra careful about nulls though.

replies.bodyText: I cut this on purpose because it's no longer needed since these methods are all synchronized now.  See the comment I removed above.  The item is added below on line 149.
replies.author: mbaxter

timeline.bodyText: Did we change our prune methodology to make it more efficient?
timeline.author: cemozerr

replies.bodyText: Yeah - added a new collection (orderedPendingItems) to track the items ordered by slot.  We can now prune things faster by only iterating over the out-of-date items.
replies.author: mbaxter

timeline.author: cemozerr

timeline.bodyText: Should we be adding the older block in the first place? if it's older than the rest of the items in PendingItems?
timeline.author: cemozerr

replies.bodyText:
Not sure how much it matters ... but I could pretty easily switch it to ignore newly added items if they're older than the oldest item.  My reasoning was that this way we're always able to add new items to the pending pool.
Thinking about possible attacks:

With the current version (always add new items):

You could flood the node with new messages and knock everything else out of the pending pool
But you'd have to keep flooding the node with new messages to keep knocking out valid items


With the version where we only keep the newest items:

You could potentially flood the node with future items and knock everything else out
Then for some period of time you could potentially block any other items from being added (until the slot ticks forward some number of times and you start to receive more messages in this range) without continuing to flood the node



It feels like the current option is a bit safer.
replies.author: mbaxter
